title: NBA 2019: Ben Simmons jump shot, Brett Brown defensive player, Paul Pierce, Joel Embiid
text:
Aussie superstar Ben Simmons is sick and tired of the daily three-point updates and he didn’t take kindly to one reporter's persistence.

Social media has been flooded with videos of Ben Simmons taking three-points shots all off-season but the Aussie star is getting sick of the scrutiny.

The 23-year-old is about to enter his third season in the NBA with the 76ers, having signed a $240 million contract extension in the off-season.

But more than that, the 76ers, led by Simmons and All-Star centre Joel Embiid want their talent to pay off with championship rings.

Many believe the secret to Simmons, who became the first Australian to play in the All-Star game last season, going to the next level is his jump shot and particularly shots from outside the arc.

He is famously 0 from 18 from three-point range in his NBA career and the criticism of why he doesn’t shoot has followed him throughout his career so far.

Simmons even put a reporter in his place when he tried to press him about his three-point shooting.

“Yeah I’ve had shots. I’ve played basketball. Come on man, that’s a dumb question”

Reporter tried to press further, saying he hadn’t made a 3 in a game.

“You’re right, I haven’t. But I’m an All-Star so …”

Philadelphia coach Brett Brown hit out at the criticism of Simmons jumper as well.

“The groundswell of this thing is bizarre,” he said. “I understand it, but it gains it’s own life and he obviously listens and I hope he doesn’t.

“If he doesn’t want to shoot, he doesn’t want to shoot. It’s always about ‘OK that sounds great, but what about April, May, and June’ and I understand that.

“You know, to me, he is a 23-year-old All-Star.”

It came as Brown tried to shift the focus, claiming Simmons could be a true force at the other end of the court.

Speaking to The Philadelphia Inquirer’s Keith Pompey, Brown said he believes Simmons has a high ceiling to reach at the defensive end.

“It’s hugely important and we understand it, especially (during the post-season),” Brown said of Simmons shooting more 3s this season. “We have to set the stage.

“But my centre point, where I see the world with him, is I think he can be the best defensive player in the NBA.”

Brown had Simmons guarding the likes of LeBron James, Giannis Antetokounmpo, Anthony Davis and Russell Westbrook and was even considered one of the more successful defenders of Kawhi Leonard as he caught fire during the second round of the playoffs.

While the comments may add more pressure to the young star, his teammate Embiid is confident Simmons will be able to get the job done.

The pair were seen shooting 3’s for the best part of an hour after training earlier in the week.

“I don’t really like shooting 3’s but this year since we have Ben willing to take those 3’s, maybe it’s going to put my game onside,” Embiid told a reporter. “I’m hoping he’ll shoot them so I can do my job inside.”

Ben working on that 3 pic.twitter.com/4q3rUA0evg — Drew Corrigan (@Dcorrigan50) October 4, 2019

While this week’s media commitments had the 76ers players remembering their second round loss to the Raptors last season with Embiid saying “I didn’t show up” and admitting he had “a lot of regrets”, Philadelphia do have some NBA legends on their side.

Former Celtics star Paul Pierce was in Sydney this week and said he expected a “monster year” for Simmons.

“He’s gonna be an All-Star, Philly will win a lot of games, and he’s probably going to be an MVP candidate,” Pierce said. “He’s one of the game’s great all-round talents already, and he’s still young.

“I expect him to improve on what he’s already done, eventually he’ll develop that jump shot, that’s the knock on him right now, but you’re gonna see greatness out of this kid.”

He also praised the 76ers recruitment in the off-season with former Celtic Al Horford singled out by Pierce as one that will help “develop his game on and off the court, developing mentally, develop him into a strong leader”.
